column2: Such conduct could not but be disagreeable to the three worthy men whose oracle I had become, but they did not like to complain.
column3: Such conduct could not but be disagreeable to the three worthy men whose oracle I had become, but they did not like to complain.

column2: The excellent M. de Bragadin would only tell me that I was giving him a repetition of the foolish life he had himself led at my age, but that I must prepare to pay the penalty of my follies, and to feel the punishment when I should reach his time of life.
column3: The excellent m de Bragadin would only tell me that I was giving him a repetition of the foolish life he had himself led at my age, but that I must prepare to pay the penalty of my follies, and to feel the punishment when I should reach his time of life.

column2: Without wanting in the respect I owed him, I would turn his terrible forebodings into jest, and continue my course of extravagance.
column3: Without wanting in the respect I owed him, I would turn his terrible forebodings into jest, and continue my course of extravagance.

column2: However, I must mention here the first proof he gave me of his true wisdom.
column3: However, I must mention here the first proof he gave me of his true wisdom.

column2: At the house of Madame Avogadro, a woman full of wit in spite of her sixty years, I had made the acquaintance of a young Polish nobleman called Zawoiski.
column3: At the house of Madame Avogadro, a woman full of wit in spite of her sixty years, I had made the acquaintance of a young Polish nobleman called Zawoiski.

column2: He was expecting money from Poland, but in the mean time the Venetian ladies did not let him want for any, being all very much in love with his handsome face and his Polish manners.
column3: He was expecting money from Poland, but in the mean time the Venetian ladies did not let him want for any, being all very much in love with his handsome face and his Polish manners.

column2: We soon became good friends, my purse was his, but, twenty years later, he assisted me to a far greater extent in Munich.
column3: We soon became good friends, my purse was his, but, twenty years later, he assisted me to a far greater extent in Munich.

column2: Zawoiski was honest, he had only a small dose of intelligence, but it was enough for his happiness.
column3: Zawoiski was honest, he had only a small dose of intelligence, but it was enough for his happiness.

column2: He died in Trieste five or six years ago, the ambassador of the Elector of Treves.
column3: He died in Trieste five or six years ago, the ambassador of the Elector of Treves.

column2: I will speak of him in another part of these Memoirs.
column3: I will speak of him in another part of these Memoirs.

column2: This amiable young man, who was a favourite with everybody and was thought a free-thinker because he frequented the society of Angelo Querini and Lunardo Venier, presented me one day, as we were out walking, to an unknown countess who took my fancy very strongly.
column3: This amiable young man, who was a favourite with everybody and was thought a free thinker because he frequented the society of Angelo Querini and Lunardo Venier, presented me one day, as we were out walking, to an unknown countess who took my fancy very strongly.

column2: We called on her in the evening, and, after introducing me to her husband, Count Rinaldi, she invited us to remain and have supper.
column3: We called on her in the evening, and, after introducing me to her husband, Count Rinaldi, she invited us to remain and have supper.

column2: The count made a faro bank in the course of the evening, I punted with his wife as a partner, and won some fifty ducats.
column3: The count made a faro bank in the course of the evening, I punted with his wife as a partner, and won some fifty ducats.

column2: Very much pleased with my new acquaintance, I called alone on the countess the next morning.
column3: Very much pleased with my new acquaintance, I called alone on the countess the next morning.

column2: The count, apologizing for his wife who was not up yet, took me to her room.
column3: The count, apologizing for his wife who was not up yet, took me to her room.

column2: She received me with graceful ease, and, her husband having left us alone, she had the art to let me hope for every favour, yet without committing herself; when I took leave of her, she invited me to supper for the evening.
column3: She received me with graceful ease, and, her husband having left us alone, she had the art to let me hope for every favour, yet without committing herself; when I took leave of her, she invited me to supper for the evening.

column2: After supper I played, still in partnership with her, won again, and went away very much in love.
column3: After supper I played, still in partnership with her, won again, and went away very much in love.

column2: I did not fail to pay her another visit the next morning, but when I presented myself at the house I was told that she had gone out.
column3: I did not fail to pay her another visit the next morning, but when I presented myself at the house I was told that she had gone out.

column2: I called again in the evening, and, after she had excused herself for not having been at home in the morning, the faro bank began, and I lost all my money, still having the countess for my partner.
column3: I called again in the evening, and, after she had excused herself for not having been at home in the morning, the faro bank began, and I lost all my money, still having the countess for my partner.

column3: After supper, and when the other guests had retired, I remained with Zawoiski, Count Rinaldi having offered to give us our revenge.

column3: As I had no more money, I played upon trust, and the count threw down the cards after I had lost five hundred sequins.

column2: I went away in great sorrow.

column3: Love increased my despair, for I saw myself on the point of losing the esteem of a woman by whom I was smitten, and the anxiety I felt did not escape m de Bragadin when we met in the morning.

column3: I dined with the three friends, and the matter was not even alluded to; but, as we were rising from the table, a servant brought m de Bragadin a letter and a parcel.

column3: I looked at m de Bragadin, perfectly amazed, and he burst out laughing. I guessed the truth, thanked him, and embracing him tenderly I promised to be wiser for the future.

column3: The mist I had before my eyes was dispelled, I felt that my love was defunct, and I remained rather ashamed, when I realized that I had been the dupe of the wife as well as of the husband.

column3: No doubt of it, for then you will save both your honour and your purse. But, as you are fond of games of chance, I advise you never to punt. Make the bank, and the advantage must be on your side.

column2: Now, as a faithful historian, I must give my readers the story of a certain adventure in which were involved the honour and happiness of one of the most charming women in Italy, who would have been unhappy if I had not been a thoughtless fellow.

column3: To a respectable house, of course.

column2: I will go to yours, if you are married.
column3: I will go to yours, if you are married.

column2: I am a bachelor.
column3: I am a bachelor.

column2: I knew an honest widow who resided in a lane, and who had two furnished rooms.
column3: I knew an honest widow who resided in a lane, and who had two furnished rooms.

column2: I persuade the young countess to follow me, and we take a gondola.
column3: I persuade the young countess to follow me, and we take a gondola.

column2: As we are gliding along, she tells me that, one month before, Steffani had stopped in her neighbourhood for necessary repairs to his travelling-carriage, and that, on the same day he had made her acquaintance at a house where she had gone with her mother for the purpose of offering their congratulations to a newly-married lady.
column3: As we are gliding along, she tells me that, one month before, Steffani had stopped in her neighbourhood for necessary repairs to his travelling carriage, and that, on the same day he had made her acquaintance at a house where she had gone with her mother for the purpose of offering their congratulations to a newly married lady.

column2: I was unfortunate enough, she continued, "to inspire him with love, and he postponed his departure.
column3: I was unfortunate enough, she continued, "to inspire him with love, and he postponed his departure.

column2: He remained one month in C----, never going out but in the evening, and spending every night under my windows conversing with me.
column3: He remained one month in C----, never going out but in the evening, and spending every night under my windows conversing with me.

column2: He swore a thousand times that he adored me, that his intentions were honourable.
column3: He swore a thousand times that he adored me, that his intentions were honourable.

column2: I entreated him to present himself to my parents to ask me in marriage, but he always excused himself by alleging some reason, good or bad, assuring me that he could not be happy unless I shewed him entire confidence.
column3: I entreated him to present himself to my parents to ask me in marriage, but he always excused himself by alleging some reason, good or bad, assuring me that he could not be happy unless I shewed him entire confidence.

column2: He would beg of me to make up my mind to run away with him, unknown to everybody, promising that my honour should not suffer from such a step, because, three days after my departure, everybody should receive notice of my being his wife, and he assured me that he would bring me back on a visit to my native place shortly after our marriage.
column3: He would beg of me to make up my mind to run away with him, unknown to everybody, promising that my honour should not suffer from such a step, because, three days after my departure, everybody should receive notice of my being his wife, and he assured me that he would bring me back on a visit to my native place shortly after our marriage.

column2: Alas, sir! what shall I say now?
column3: Alas, sir! what shall I say now?

column2: Love blinded me; I fell into the abyss; I believed him; I agreed to everything.
column3: Love blinded me; I fell into the abyss; I believed him; I agreed to everything.

column2: He gave me the paper which you have read, and the following night I allowed him to come into my room through the window under which he was in the habit of conversing with me.
column3: He gave me the paper which you have read, and the following night I allowed him to come into my room through the window under which he was in the habit of conversing with me.

column2: I consented to be guilty of a crime which I believed would be atoned for within three days, and he left me, promising that the next night he would be again under my window, ready to receive me in his arms.	I consented to be guilty of a crime which I believed would be atoned for within three days, and he left me, promising that the next night he would be again under my window, ready to receive me in his arms.
column3: true

column2: Could I possibly entertain any doubt after the fearful crime I had committed for him?
column3: Could I possibly entertain any doubt after the fearful crime I had committed for him?

column2: I prepared a small parcel, and waited for his coming, but in vain. Oh! what a cruel long night it was!
column3: I prepared a small parcel, and waited for his coming, but in vain. Oh! what a cruel long night it was!

column2: In the morning I heard that the monster had gone away with his servant one hour after sealing my shame. You may imagine my despair!
column3: In the morning I heard that the monster had gone away with his servant one hour after sealing my shame. You may imagine my despair!

column2: I adopted the only plan that despair could suggest, and that, of course, was not the right one.
column3: I adopted the only plan that despair could suggest, and that, of course, was not the right one.

column2: One hour before midnight I left my father's roof, alone, thus completing my dishonour, but resolved on death, if the man who has cruelly robbed me of my most precious treasure, and whom a natural instinct told me I could find here, does not restore me the honour which he alone can give me back.
column3: One hour before midnight I left my father's roof, alone, thus completing my dishonour, but resolved on death, if the man who has cruelly robbed me of my most precious treasure, and whom a natural instinct told me I could find here, does not restore me the honour which he alone can give me back.

column2: I walked all night and nearly the whole day, without taking any food, until I got into the barge, which brought me here in twenty-four hours. I travelled in the boat with five men and two women, but no one saw my face or heard my voice, I kept constantly sitting down in a corner, holding my head down, half asleep, and with this prayer-book in my hands.
column3: I walked all night and nearly the whole day, without taking any food, until I got into the barge, which brought me here in twenty four hours. I travelled in the boat with five men and two women, but no one saw my face or heard my voice, I kept constantly sitting down in a corner, holding my head down, half asleep, and with this prayer book in my hands.

column2: I was left alone, no one spoke to me, and I thanked God for it. When I landed on the wharf, you did not give me time to think how I could find out the dwelling of my perfidious seducer, but you may imagine the impression produced upon me by the sudden apparition of a masked man who, abruptly, and as if placed there purposely by Providence, offered me his services; it seemed to me that you had guessed my distress, and, far from experiencing any repugnance, I felt that I was acting rightly in trusting myself in your hands, in spite of all prudence which, perhaps, ought to have made me turn a deaf ear to your words, and refuse the invitation to enter alone with you the house to which you took me.
column3: I was left alone, no one spoke to me, and I thanked God for it. When I landed on the wharf, you did not give me time to think how I could find out the dwelling of my perfidious seducer, but you may imagine the impression produced upon me by the sudden apparition of a masked man who, abruptly, and as if placed there purposely by Providence, offered me his services; it seemed to me that you had guessed my distress, and, far from experiencing any repugnance, I felt that I was acting rightly in trusting myself in your hands, in spite of all prudence which, perhaps, ought to have made me turn a deaf ear to your words, and refuse the invitation to enter alone with you the house to which you took me.

column2: You know all now, sir; but I entreat you not to judge me too severely; I have been virtuous all through my life; one month ago I had never committed a fault which could call a blush upon my face, and the bitter tears which I shed every day will, I hope, wash out my crime in the eyes of God.	You know all now, sir; but I entreat you not to judge me too severely; I have been virtuous all through my life; one month ago I had never committed a fault which could call a blush upon my face, and the bitter tears which I shed every day will, I hope, wash out my crime in the eyes of God.
column3: true

column2: I have been carefully brought up, but love and the want of experience have thrown me into the abyss.
column3: I have been carefully brought up, but love and the want of experience have thrown me into the abyss.

column2: I am in your hands, and I feel certain that I shall have no cause to repent it."
column3: I am in your hands, and I feel certain that I shall have no cause to repent it."

column2: I needed all she had just told' me to confirm me in the interest which I had felt in her from the first moment.
column3: I needed all she had just told' me to confirm me in the interest which I had felt in her from the first moment.

column2: I told her unsparingly that Steffani had seduced and abandoned her of malice aforethought, and that she ought to think of him only to be revenged of his perfidy.
column3: I told her unsparingly that Steffani had seduced and abandoned her of malice aforethought, and that she ought to think of him only to be revenged of his perfidy.

column2: My words made her shudder, and she buried her beautiful face in her hands.
column3: My words made her shudder, and she buried her beautiful face in her hands.

column2: We reached the widow's house.
column3: We reached the widow's house.

column2: I established her in a pretty, comfortable room, and ordered some supper for her, desiring the good landlady to skew her every attention and to let her want for nothing.
column3: I established her in a pretty, comfortable room, and ordered some supper for her, desiring the good landlady to skew her every attention and to let her want for nothing.

column2: I then took an affectionate leave of her, promising to see her early in the morning.
column3: I then took an affectionate leave of her, promising to see her early in the morning.

column2: On leaving this interesting but hapless girl, I proceeded to the house of Steffani.
column3: On leaving this interesting but hapless girl, I proceeded to the house of Steffani.

column2: I heard from one of his mother's gondoliers that he had returned to Venice three days before, but that, twenty-four hours after his return, he had gone away again without any servant, and nobody knew his whereabouts, not even his mother.
column3: I heard from one of his mother's gondoliers that he had returned to Venice three days before, but that, twenty four hours after his return, he had gone away again without any servant, and nobody knew his whereabouts, not even his mother.

column2: The same evening, happening to be seated next to an abbe from Bologna at the theatre, I asked him several questions respecting the family of my unfortunate protegee.
column3: The same evening, happening to be seated next to an abbe from Bologna at the theatre, I asked him several questions respecting the family of my unfortunate protegee.

column2: The abbe being intimately acquainted with them, I gathered from him all the information I required, and, amongst other things, I heard that the young countess had a brother, then an officer in the papal service.
column3: The abbe being intimately acquainted with them, I gathered from him all the information I required, and, amongst other things, I heard that the young countess had a brother, then an officer in the papal service.

column2: Very early the next morning I called upon her.
column3: Very early the next morning I called upon her.

column2: She was still asleep.
column3: She was still asleep.

column2: The widow told me that she had made a pretty good supper, but without speaking a single word, and that she had locked herself up in her room immediately afterwards.
column3: The widow told me that she had made a pretty good supper, but without speaking a single word, and that she had locked herself up in her room immediately afterwards.

column2: As soon as she had opened her door, I entered her room, and, cutting short her apologies for having kept me waiting, I informed her of all I had heard.
column3: As soon as she had opened her door, I entered her room, and, cutting short her apologies for having kept me waiting, I informed her of all I had heard.

column2: Her features bore the stamp of deep sorrow, but she looked calmer, and her complexion was no longer pale.
column3: Her features bore the stamp of deep sorrow, but she looked calmer, and her complexion was no longer pale.

column2: She thought it unlikely that Steffani would have left for any other place but for C----.
column3: She thought it unlikely that Steffani would have left for any other place but for C----.

column2: Admitting the possibility that she might be right, I immediately offered to go to C--- - myself, and to return without loss of time to fetch her, in case Steffani should be there.
column3: Admitting the possibility that she might be right, I immediately offered to go to C--- - myself, and to return without loss of time to fetch her, in case Steffani should be there.

column2: Without giving her time to answer I told her all the particulars I had learned concerning her honourable family, which caused her real satisfaction.
column3: Without giving her time to answer I told her all the particulars I had learned concerning her honourable family, which caused her real satisfaction.

column2: I have no objection, she said, "to your going to C----, and I thank you for the generosity of your offer, but I beg you will postpone your journey.
column3: I have no objection, she said, "to your going to C----, and I thank you for the generosity of your offer, but I beg you will postpone your journey.

column2: I still hope that Steffani will return, and then I can take a decision."
column3: I still hope that Steffani will return, and then I can take a decision."

column2: I think you are quite right, I said.
column3: I think you are quite right, I said.

column2: Will you allow me to have some breakfast with you?
column3: Will you allow me to have some breakfast with you?

column2: Do you suppose I could refuse you?
column3: Do you suppose I could refuse you?

column2: I should be very sorry to disturb you in any way.	I should be very sorry to disturb you in any way.
column3: true

column2: How did you use to amuse yourself at home?"
column3: How did you use to amuse yourself at home?"

column2: I am very fond of books and music; my harpsichord was my delight.
column3: I am very fond of books and music; my harpsichord was my delight.

column2: I left her after breakfast, and in the evening I came back with a basket full of good books and music, and I sent her an excellent harpsichord. My kindness confused her, but I surprised her much more when I took out of my pocket three pairs of slippers.
column3: I left her after breakfast, and in the evening I came back with a basket full of good books and music, and I sent her an excellent harpsichord. My kindness confused her, but I surprised her much more when I took out of my pocket three pairs of slippers.

column2: She blushed, and thanked me with great feeling.
column3: She blushed, and thanked me with great feeling.

column2: She had walked a long distance, her shoes were evidently worn out, her feet sore, and she appreciated the delicacy of my present. As I had no improper design with regard to her, I enjoyed her gratitude, and felt pleased at the idea she evidently entertained of my kind attentions.
column3: She had walked a long distance, her shoes were evidently worn out, her feet sore, and she appreciated the delicacy of my present. As I had no improper design with regard to her, I enjoyed her gratitude, and felt pleased at the idea she evidently entertained of my kind attentions.

column2: I had no other purpose in view but to restore calm to her mind, and to obliterate the bad opinion which the unworthy Steffani had given her of men in general.
column3: I had no other purpose in view but to restore calm to her mind, and to obliterate the bad opinion which the unworthy Steffani had given her of men in general.

column2: I never thought of inspiring her with love for me, and I had not the slightest idea that I could fall in love with her.
column3: I never thought of inspiring her with love for me, and I had not the slightest idea that I could fall in love with her.

column2: She was unhappy, and her unhappiness--a sacred thing in my eyes-- called all the more for my most honourable sympathy, because, without knowing me, she had given me her entire confidence.
column3: She was unhappy, and her unhappiness-a sacred thing in my eyes- called all the more for my most honourable sympathy, because, without knowing me, she had given me her entire confidence.

column2: Situated as she was, I could not suppose her heart susceptible of harbouring a new affection, and I would have despised myself if I had tried to seduce her by any means in my power.
column3: Situated as she was, I could not suppose her heart susceptible of harbouring a new affection, and I would have despised myself if I had tried to seduce her by any means in my power.

column2: I remained with her only a quarter of an hour, being unwilling that my presence should trouble her at such a moment, as she seemed to be at a loss how to thank me and to express all her gratitude.
column3: I remained with her only a quarter of an hour, being unwilling that my presence should trouble her at such a moment, as she seemed to be at a loss how to thank me and to express all her gratitude.

column2: I was thus engaged in a rather delicate adventure, the end of which I could not possibly foresee, but my warmth for my protegee did not cool down, and having no difficulty in procuring the means to keep her I had no wish to see the last scene of the romance.
column3: I was thus engaged in a rather delicate adventure, the end of which I could not possibly foresee, but my warmth for my protegee did not cool down, and having no difficulty in procuring the means to keep her I had no wish to see the last scene of the romance.

column2: That singular meeting, which gave me the useful opportunity of finding myself endowed with generous dispositions, stronger even than my love for pleasure, flattered my self-love more than I could express.
column3: That singular meeting, which gave me the useful opportunity of finding myself endowed with generous dispositions, stronger even than my love for pleasure, flattered my self love more than I could express.

column2: I was then trying a great experiment, and conscious that I wanted sadly to study myself, I gave up all my energies to acquire the great science of the 'xxxxxxxxxxxx'.
column3: I was then trying a great experiment, and conscious that I wanted sadly to study myself, I gave up all my energies to acquire the great science of the 'x x x x x x x x x x x x'.

column2: On the third day, in the midst of expressions of gratitude which I could not succeed in stopping she told me that she could not conceive why I shewed her so much sympathy, because I ought to have formed but a poor opinion of her in consequence of the readiness with which she had followed me into the cafe.
column3: On the third day, in the midst of expressions of gratitude which I could not succeed in stopping she told me that she could not conceive why I shewed her so much sympathy, because I ought to have formed but a poor opinion of her in consequence of the readiness with which she had followed me into the cafe.

column2: She smiled when I answered that I could not understand how I had succeeded in giving her so great a confidence in my virtue, when I appeared before her with a mask on my face, in a costume which did not indicate a very virtuous character.
column3: She smiled when I answered that I could not understand how I had succeeded in giving her so great a confidence in my virtue, when I appeared before her with a mask on my face, in a costume which did not indicate a very virtuous character.

column2: It was easy for me, madam, I continued, "to guess that you were a beauty in distress, when I observed your youth, the nobleness of your countenance, and, more than all, your candour.
column3: It was easy for me, madam, I continued, "to guess that you were a beauty in distress, when I observed your youth, the nobleness of your countenance, and, more than all, your candour.

column2: The stamp of truth was so well affixed to the first words you uttered that I could not have the shadow of a doubt left in me as to your being the unhappy victim of the most natural of all feelings, and as to your having abandoned your home through a sentiment of honour.
column3: The stamp of truth was so well affixed to the first words you uttered that I could not have the shadow of a doubt left in me as to your being the unhappy victim of the most natural of all feelings, and as to your having abandoned your home through a sentiment of honour.

column2: Your fault was that of a warm heart seduced by love, over which reason could have no sway, and your flight-- the action of a soul crying for reparation or for revenge-fully justifies you.
column3: Your fault was that of a warm heart seduced by love, over which reason could have no sway, and your flight- the action of a soul crying for reparation or for revenge fully justifies you.

column2: Your cowardly seducer must pay with his life the penalty due to his crime, and he ought never to receive, by marrying you, an unjust reward, for he is not worthy of possessing you after degrading himself by the vilest conduct."
column3: Your cowardly seducer must pay with his life the penalty due to his crime, and he ought never to receive, by marrying you, an unjust reward, for he is not worthy of possessing you after degrading himself by the vilest conduct."

column2: Everything you say is true.	Everything you say is true.
column3: true

column2: My brother, I hope, will avenge me."
column3: My brother, I hope, will avenge me."

column2: You are greatly mistaken if you imagine that Steffani will fight your brother; Steffani is a coward who will never expose himself to an honourable death.
column3: You are greatly mistaken if you imagine that Steffani will fight your brother; Steffani is a coward who will never expose himself to an honourable death.

column2: As I was speaking, she put her hand in her pocket and drew forth, after a few moments' consideration, a stiletto six inches long, which she placed on the table.
column3: As I was speaking, she put her hand in her pocket and drew forth, after a few moments' consideration, a stiletto six inches long, which she placed on the table.

column2: What is this? I exclaimed.
column3: What is this? I exclaimed.

column2: It is a weapon upon which I reckoned until now to use against myself in case I should not succeed in obtaining reparation for the crime I have committed.	It is a weapon upon which I reckoned until now to use against myself in case I should not succeed in obtaining reparation for the crime I have committed.

column2: But you have opened my eyes.
column3: But you have opened my eyes.

column2: Take away, I entreat you, this stiletto, which henceforth is useless to me.
column3: Take away, I entreat you, this stiletto, which henceforth is useless to me.

column2: I trust in your friendship, and I have an inward certainty that I shall be indebted to you for my honour as well as for my life."
column3: I trust in your friendship, and I have an inward certainty that I shall be indebted to you for my honour as well as for my life."

column2: I was struck by the words she had just uttered, and I felt that those words, as well as her looks, had found their way to my heart, besides enlisting my generous sympathy.
column3: I was struck by the words she had just uttered, and I felt that those words, as well as her looks, had found their way to my heart, besides enlisting my generous sympathy.

column2: I took the stiletto, and left her with so much agitation that I had to acknowledge the weakness of my heroism, which I was very near turning into ridicule; yet I had the wonderful strength to perform, at least by halves, the character of a Cato until the seventh day.
column3: I took the stiletto, and left her with so much agitation that I had to acknowledge the weakness of my heroism, which I was very near turning into ridicule; yet I had the wonderful strength to perform, at least by halves, the character of a Cato until the seventh day.

column2: I must explain how a certain suspicion of the young lady arose in my mind.
column3: I must explain how a certain suspicion of the young lady arose in my mind.

column2: That doubt was heavy on my heart, for, if it had proved true, I should have been a dupe, and the idea was humiliating.
column3: That doubt was heavy on my heart, for, if it had proved true, I should have been a dupe, and the idea was humiliating.

column2: She had told me that she was a musician; I had immediately sent her a harpsichord, and, yet, although the instrument had been at her disposal for three days, she had not opened it once, for the widow had told me so.
column3: She had told me that she was a musician; I had immediately sent her a harpsichord, and, yet, although the instrument had been at her disposal for three days, she had not opened it once, for the widow had told me so.

column2: It seemed to me that the best way to thank me for my attentive kindness would have been to give me a specimen of her musical talent.
column3: It seemed to me that the best way to thank me for my attentive kindness would have been to give me a specimen of her musical talent.

column2: Had she deceived me? If so, she would lose my esteem.
column3: Had she deceived me? If so, she would lose my esteem.

column2: But, unwilling to form a hasty judgment, I kept on my guard, with a firm determination to make good use of the first opportunity that might present itself to clear up my doubts.
column3: But, unwilling to form a hasty judgment, I kept on my guard, with a firm determination to make good use of the first opportunity that might present itself to clear up my doubts.

column2: I called upon her the next day after dinner, which was not my usual time, having resolved on creating the opportunity myself.
column3: I called upon her the next day after dinner, which was not my usual time, having resolved on creating the opportunity myself.

column2: I caught her seated before a toilet-glass, while the widow dressed the most beautiful auburn hair I had ever seen.
column3: I caught her seated before a toilet glass, while the widow dressed the most beautiful auburn hair I had ever seen.

column2: I tendered my apologies for my sudden appearance at an unusual hour; she excused herself for not having completed her toilet, and the widow went on with her work.
column3: I tendered my apologies for my sudden appearance at an unusual hour; she excused herself for not having completed her toilet, and the widow went on with her work.

column2: It was the first time I had seen the whole of her face, her neck, and half of her arms, which the graces themselves had moulded.
column3: It was the first time I had seen the whole of her face, her neck, and half of her arms, which the graces themselves had moulded.

column2: I remained in silent contemplation.
column3: I remained in silent contemplation.

column2: I praised, quite by chance, the perfume of the pomatum, and the widow took the opportunity of telling her that she had spent in combs, powder, and pomatum the three livres she had received from her.
column3: I praised, quite by chance, the perfume of the pomatum, and the widow took the opportunity of telling her that she had spent in combs, powder, and pomatum the three livres she had received from her.

column2: I recollected then that she had told me the first day that she had left C- --- with ten paoli.
column3: I recollected then that she had told me the first day that she had left C --- with ten paoli.

column2: I blushed for very shame, for I ought to have thought of that.

column2: As soon as the widow had dressed her hair, she left the room to prepare some coffee for us.
column3: As soon as the widow had dressed her hair, she left the room to prepare some coffee for us.

column2: I took up a ring which had been laid by her on the toilet-table, and I saw that it contained a portrait exactly like her; I was amused at the singular fancy she had had of having her likeness taken in a man's costume, with black hair.
column3: I took up a ring which had been laid by her on the toilet table, and I saw that it contained a portrait exactly like her; I was amused at the singular fancy she had had of having her likeness taken in a man's costume, with black hair.

column2: You are mistaken, she said, "it is a portrait of my brother.

column2: He is two years older than I, and is an officer in the papal army."

column3: I begged her permission to put the ring on her finger; she consented, and when I tried, out of mere gallantry, to kiss her hand, she drew it back, blushing.

column2: I feared she might be offended, and I assured her of my respect.
column3: I feared she might be offended, and I assured her of my respect.

column3: Ah, sir! she answered, "in the situation in which I am placed, I must think of defending myself against my own self much more than against you."

column2: The compliment struck me as so fine, and so complimentary to me, that I thought it better not to take it up, but she could easily read in my eyes that she would never find me ungrateful for whatever feelings she might entertain in my favour.
column3: The compliment struck me as so fine, and so complimentary to me, that I thought it better not to take it up, but she could easily read in my eyes that she would never find me ungrateful for whatever feelings she might entertain in my favour.

column2: Yet I felt my love taking such proportions that I did not know how to keep it a mystery any longer.
column3: Yet I felt my love taking such proportions that I did not know how to keep it a mystery any longer.

column2: Soon after that, as she was again thanking me for the books--I had given her, saying that I had guessed her taste exactly, because she did not like novels, she added, "I owe you an apology for not having sung to you yet, knowing that you are fond of music." column2: I entreated her to sing; after some little ceremony, she took one of the music books I had given her, and she sang at sight in a manner which fairly ravished me.
column3: I entreated her to sing; after some little ceremony, she took one of the music books I had given her, and she sang at sight in a manner which fairly ravished me.

column2: I begged that she would allow me to kiss her hand, and she did not say yes, but when I took it and pressed my lips on it, she did not oppose any resistance; I had the courage to smother my ardent desires, and the kiss I imprinted on her lovely hand was a mixture of tenderness, respect, and admiration.
column3: I begged that she would allow me to kiss her hand, and she did not say yes, but when I took it and pressed my lips on it, she did not oppose any resistance; I had the courage to smother my ardent desires, and the kiss I imprinted on her lovely hand was a mixture of tenderness, respect, and admiration.

column2: I took leave of her, smitten, full of love, and almost determined on declaring my passion.
column3: I took leave of her, smitten, full of love, and almost determined on declaring my passion.
